query: Burning bush[Title] AND (therapy[Title/Abstract] OR treatment[Title/Abstract] OR intervention[Title/Abstract])

articles.title: [Bullous phototoxic contact dermatitis caused by Dictamnus albus. The Bible's "burning bush"?].
articles.abstract: A bullous phototoxic reaction occurred in a 27-year-old man working with the plant Dictamnus albus. The skin changes disappeared, leaving behind areas of hyperpigmentation, after treatment with corticoid-containing ointments. Possible causes are 5- and 8-methoxypsoralen, perhaps also photodynamically active alkaloids of the plant, as well as sun-ray exposure and sweating. Dictamnus albus may be the biblical "burning bush". Since the plant becoming ever more popular in German gardens, a phytophototoxic reaction should be considered in the differential diagnosis of the described symptoms.
